IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Foxdale Village is a not-for-profit Quaker-directed continuing care retirement community.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Foxdale Village is a not-for-profit Quaker-directed continuing care retirement community. Through community services and programs, Foxdale provides for the social, spiritual, nutritional, residential, wellness and health care needs of older people at reasonable cost while providing a supportive working environment for employees. Our community is based on Quaker values and Quaker conviction that all people are to be treated with dignity and loving respect.
IRS990.Description: In 2010 Foxdale Village celebrates its 20th anniversary as a continuing care retirement community dedicated to serving men and women over the age of 65 in State College Pennsylvania. Foxdale's mission is to promote wellness and independence throughout the course of a lifespan. To achieve this goal and that of its role as a CCRC, Foxdale provides or makes available for a modest fee housing, health care, therapeutic recreation, exercise programs, an on site clinic and other related services. The majority of Foxdale residents live in cottages but are able to move into nursing or personal care facilities as appropriate to their situation. Foxdale has 32 licensed nursing beds, 35 personal care units and 148 residential living apartments. In the 2010 fiscal year, Foxdale served 264 residents and their families while employing over 250 individuals. Foxdale is in the midst of a $40 million expansion which will add 57 apartments, a memory support neighborhood, additional personal care rooms and a renovated community building housing the cafe and other services.Founded by a group of State College Friends, Foxdale Village is guided by Quaker principles and is the caring community those founders envisioned. That care is evident among residents through the breadth and depth of activities of the Resident's Association, individual resident volunteers, their family members, and in the staff who serve residents. That care also extends to Centre County and beyond as residents and staff engage in an array of volunteer and philanthropic activities. Foxdale residents volunteer and spearhead activity for an array of local nonprofits. Administrators and staff serve on and lead boards, speak to groups about healthy aging and life transitions, participate in mentoring programs for aspiring college students and other professionals in the health care field and much more. Thanks to the philanthropic vision of the first board and gifts from residents, family members and others, The Community Fund is available to aid residents with the cost of care should their financial fortunes change. Residents and others have also employed philanthropy to honor and thank employees for their exemplary service by supporting three funds that provide no-interest loans, support housing costs or fund continuing education. Thanks to the exemplary efforts of staff, 47% of whom have worked at Foxdale for over five years, Foxdale continues to be one of the highest rated health care providers in the Centre County region. Year after year, the survey results of the various governing agencies, along with the comments from Foxdale residents and their families, affirm the organization's commitment to its residents and mission statement. To ensure the quality of service to residents, Foxdale participated in a quality improvement program regarding various risk management topics in 2010. Foxdale ranked in the top twenty-fifth percentile of all the communities participating. Foxdale's neighborhoods and beautiful grounds, opportunities for intellectual engagement, and commitment to sustainability are just a few of the reasons residents and others highly rate Foxdale.From a financial perspective, Foxdale is on firm footing. Foxdale has maintained a positive increase in cash from operations and investments despite the overall downturn in the investment market. The 2010 fiscal year resulted in a 94% occupancy rate while the waiting list remains strong with 150 perspective residents. Twenty of these residents plan on moving to Foxdale in the next twelve months. Thanks to this strong position, Foxdale has been able to continue to invest in ongoing infrastructure improvements. Planning has continued to take place in the past year for the future of Foxdale. The board has authorized a new strategic plan and also approved the expansion project mentioned earlier. To view site plans, floor plans, a video rendering and Web cam access to daily construction progress please visit: http://foxdalevillage.org/expansion.html.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Corporation accounts for uncertainty in income taxes using a recognition threshold of more-likely-than-not to be sustained upon examination by the appropriate tax authority. Measurement of the tax uncertainty occurs if the recognition threshold has been met. Management has determined that there were no tax uncertainties that met the recognition threshold in 2010 and 2009.
Change in value of charitable gift annuities: 14300.
CHANGE IN VALUE OF CHARITABLE GIFT ANNUITIES: 14300.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Requests for assistance are made initially through the Director of Financial Services who will take the request to the Community Fund Assistance Committee for review. The Committee consists of the Executive Director, the Director of Financial Services, and the Clerk of the Foxdale Corporate Board. The Committee will make a decision pertaining to assistance based on complete information on the resident's financial circumstances. The decision will be based on the resident maintaining a reasonable standard of living. The Director of Financial Services will review the subsidy on a periodic basis based on increases in cost of living, Foxdale's fees and the resident's income.

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.Relationship: FATHER AND BROTHER OF THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL SERVICES
Form990ScheduleLPartIV.DescriptionOfTransaction: Both the Maintenance and Environmental Services departments purchase goods and services from Top to Bottom Interiors which is owned and operated by the father and brother of the Director of Financial Services. In the 2009/2010 fiscal year the purchases were primarily for carpet installation along with window coverings which are used in resident apartments. All of these services and purchases were made by the Directors for Maintenance and Environmental Services with no involvement from the Director of Financial Services. These transactions were conducted at arm's length and fair market value compensation was paid for material and services.

Northwest Savings Bank has been chosen as the lead lender for Foxdale's expansion project. Northwest was asked to bid on the project along with over seven other banks. Foxdale hired an independent financial advisor to assist the Board in evaluting the proposals and to make a final proposal to the Board. Both the financial advisor and the Board felt that Northwest Savings Banks proposal was the best of all the banks. Myra is a loan officer at Northwest Savings Bank and will be the lender on the account. Myra did not participate in any of the discussions relating to the financing.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Mardy Shaw is the mother of Richard Shaw. Both of these individuals are members of our Board of Directors.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The information used in the 990 was prepared primarily by the director of Financial Services who provided this information to the auditing firm ParenteBeard. ParenteBeard prepared the 990 and submitted it back to the Finance and Property Committee where it was reviewed at the November Committee meeting. The Committee then forwarded the document to the Board of Directors for their December meeting at which time it was approved. After approval, ParenteBeard was asked to submit the 990 to the IRS.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All Board members and key employees must submit a conflict of interest statement and these statements are reviewed by each Board member at their August meeting. Individual Board members are encouraged to ask questions regarding anyone with a conflict at that meeting and the Board would decide if they feel the conflict is large enough to require action. No such conflict existed in 2009/2010.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board of Directors reviews and approves the salary for the Executive Director on an annual basis. The primary tool for comparitive purposes are annual salary surveys. All other employee compensation rates established by the Executive Director and the Director of Human Resources. They also use annual salary surveys for establishing compensation rates as well and they also use comparitive data from local sources.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: These documents are available by request from the Administration of Foxdale Village and have been included in Board Meeting packets when they are reviewed, changed and approved. The Board Meeting packets are available to the public in the Foxdale Village library.

FORM 990, PART IX, STATEMENT OF FUNCTIONAL EXPENSES WAS AMENDED TO ALLOCATE SALARIES AND BENEFITS FOR THE ORGANIZATION'S DEVELOPMENT OFFICER AND RELATED OFFICE SUPPLY EXPENSES FROM MANAGEMENT AND GENERAL EXPENSES TO FUNDRAISING EXPENSES.
